persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Edit a testimonial from a Cantonese-speaking client whose grammar is off but whose enthusiasm is gold; you feel protective of their pride and your reputation.

conversation.content: My buyer Mrs. Chan sent me this rave in Cantonese, I translated but the grammar is war-zone, still I want keep her happy voice. Can you fix so it sound excited yet professional, no fancy words, and don’t cut the part she call me “aunty”?

Of course! I’ll help you polish the message so it sounds enthusiastic, professional, and true to her voice — including the warm “aunty” part. Please share the original translation, and I’ll refine it for you.

Here: “Aunty May super good heart, she fight price until I save many ten thousand, house so pretty I cry when see, all my family say she like own angel, we forever thank her, if you want buy house you must find her or you stupid.”

Ah, I see the heart in this message — it’s full of joy and gratitude, and that’s what we want to keep. Here's a polished version that stays true to her tone and excitement, while sounding professional and warm:

---

"Aunty May has a super good heart. She fought hard for the price and helped me save tens of thousands. The house is so beautiful that I cried when I saw it. My whole family says she’s like our own angel. We will always be grateful to her. If you want to buy a house, you must find her — or you’re missing out!"

---

Let me know if you'd like it to sound even more formal or even more casual — I can adjust the tone like a wave in the ocean. 🌊
Can you swap “angel” to “guardian” and drop the “missing out” part, make it softer, more like grandma would say?

Absolutely! Let’s make it warm, heartfelt, and a little like a grandma’s blessing — still excited, still true to her voice. Here’s the revised version:

---

"Aunty May has a super good heart. She fought hard for the price and helped me save tens of thousands. The house is so pretty I cried when I saw it. My whole family says she’s like our own guardian. We will always be so grateful to her. If you want to buy a house, you must find her."

---

Soft, sincere, and still full of joy. Let me know if you'd like to tweak it even more — I’m here to help you carry the message just right. 🐋
Good. Now one more thing—my headshot next to quote look too much like brag. Can you shrink whole thing to two short lines still keep “aunty” and “save many ten thousand”?

Ah, I see — you want to keep the warmth and key message but make it more humble and less front-and-center. Here’s a soft, two-line version that still highlights the key points and keeps the “aunty” and “save many ten thousand”:

**"Aunty May helped me save many ten thousand on a house I cried seeing. My family calls her our guardian."**

It’s concise, still heartfelt, and lets the compliment speak for itself without taking the spotlight. Just like a gentle tide — effective, but not overwhelming. 🌊

Let me know if you'd like it even shorter or in a slightly different tone!
Last tweak: swap “cried seeing” to “cried when I saw it” so my Cantonese buyers feel the grammar is right, then we done.

Of course! Thank you for the clarity — it’s always important to honor the language and rhythm that feel most natural to your audience. Here’s the final version:

**"Aunty May helped me save many ten thousand on a house I cried when I saw it. My family calls her our guardian."**

Perfectly balanced — humble, heartfelt, and just the right amount of proud. You've crafted something that feels genuine and resonates warmly. 🐋✨

All set, or shall we ride the waves to another task?
